user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun(osal_id_t timebase_id, uint32 *freerun_val)
{
    int32                          return_code;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(freerun_val);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, timebase_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, token);

        *freerun_val = timebase->freerun_time;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found. Analysis: 
- The function parameters are 'timebase_id' (by value) and 'freerun_val' (pointer). There is no assignment to either parameter identifier in the function body (no statements like 'timebase_id = ...' or 'freerun_val = ...').
- The only write involving the pointer parameter is '*freerun_val = timebase->freerun_time;', which modifies the object referred to by the pointer (allowed by Rule 17.8), not the pointer itself.
- OS_CHECK_POINTER(freerun_val) expands to a NULL check macro and does not assign to the parameter; it only evaluates the pointer for NULL (the macro shown is BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,...)).
- Calls to other functions (OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) pass values or the address of a local token variable; they do not alter the function’s own parameters. Any modification of pointer parameters would need to occur inside those called functions, which would be investigated in their own implementations if necessary.
Given the code shown, there are no places where a function parameter is modified, so no fragments require further investigation for Rule 17.8.
